awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: The Study of Nuclear Physics with Intermediate Energy Probes
awd_abstract_narration:
Although ninety-eight percent of the mass of ordinary matter is due to the strong subatomic force, the present theory of that force (Quantum Chromodynamics) is still not fully understood. This award supports the study of the strong force by probing the substructure of matter. Almost the entire mass of an atom is concentrated in its tiny nucleus, which is made of nucleons that are either positively charged (protons) or electrically neutral (neutrons). These subatomic particles, however, are not elementary but are themselves composite objects made of quarks held together by glue particles (gluons). The structure of nucleons is a manifestation of the strong force, which is indeed the strongest force known. This project helps to address overarching questions about the origin of most of the visible mass in the universe, the nature of neutron stars, the properties of dense nuclear matter, and the structure of nucleons. Answering these and related questions is a complex task requiring dedicated experimental observations and careful testing of theoretical predictions against measured observations. This research will help discovery in and advance understanding of nuclear physics, and will promote teaching, training, and learning. The preparation of junior scientists plays a central role in the supported activities.

The nuclear physics research program at the University of South Carolina (USC) is based at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (JLab) in Newport News, Virginia and the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. At JLab, the group uses high-energy electron and photon beams along with sophisticated particle detectors, that were developed, in part, at USC, as powerful microscopes to study the structure and interaction of baryons. This research program will continue to provide crucial high-precision,polarized and unpolarized, electro- and photo-production observables that will pin down present problems in strong QCD. Complete and mostly complete meson-photoproduction measurements will settle in an almost model-independent way lingering problems in baryon spectroscopy and in particular verify the SU(6)xO(3) three quark baryon structure. Alternatively, the structure of baryons can be probed through their interactions in scattering processes. The study of strong interactions involving the strange quark is essential to understand the properties of neutron stars. This project carries a comprehensive study of hyperon photo-production off deuterons. The extensive set of single- and double-polarization observables will provide long-needed information from experiments on the hyperon-nucleon interaction. The properties of hadrons are modified in the medium as a consequence of the partial restoration of chiral symmetry and many-body effects. The bound proton electromagnetic form factors in He-4 may be modified compared to those in the vacuum as revealed for the first time by the group's earlier measurements. The upcoming USC experiment on He-4, H-2, and H-1 at JLab will confirm or refute these results. The observations of such phenomena are potentially transformative in the way we view hadrons and their interactions in nuclear matter. At PSI, the group is preparing the MUSE experiment. This precision experiment will address the proton-radius puzzle by scattering muons and electrons off the proton.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The study of the atomic nucleus and its constituents at the quark level is at the core of the research of the experimental nuclear physics group at the University of South Carolina. We have been leading experiments at one of the flagship facilities for nuclear physics research in the U.S., the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (JLab) and at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. We have also been engaged in collaborative research at the electron accelerator MAMI in Germany and have been responsible for the construction and maintenance of critical equipment for major nuclear-physics experiments at JLab and PSI.

The strong force is one of the four fundamental forces of nature, the other three being gravity, electromagnetism, and the weak force. It governs the interaction of quarks and gluons that are the fundamental building blocks of protons and neutrons (also called nucleons). Nucleons are the constituents of nuclei, which are the foundation of living and non-living matter. While a lot of evidentiary record has been collected about the existence and the properties of nuclei, nucleons, and other particles composed of quarks and gluons, there are many remaining mysteries about the force acting between quarks and gluons the unraveling of which is critical for our understanding of the visible world. Our studies focus on Quantum ChromoDynamics (QCD), humanity's most advanced hypothesis of how the force between quark and gluons works.  The results from our research will ultimately help address fundamental questions such as: how is the visible mass in the universe generated, why do quarks and gluons not exist as free particles, what is the nature of neutron stars, and what are the properties of dense nuclear matter? Answering these questions is a complex task requiring dedicated experimental observations and careful testing of theoretical predictions against these observations.

A major outcome of this project is the measurement of large sets of observables for various nuclear reactions at JLab.  These novel high-precision results are used in theoretical calculations to shed light on the spectrum of nucleon excitations and their structure.  In fact, our published data were instrumental to establish evidence for poorly known and new nucleon excited states.  Our results also drive the development of theoretical calculations to unveil details about the force acting between the quarks as they create ground and excited states. A unique, novel set of data collected at JLab, will provide for first time quantitative insight into the gluon structure of the lightest nucleus, the deuteron. While it is generally known that the force between a strange and an up quark is different from the force between an up and a down quark, we are lacking precise details on this broken symmetry. Our most recent work provides critical data to discriminate between different hypotheses about the numerical characteristics of these forces.

In addition to these scientific results, we developed critical equipment for two forefront nuclear-physics experiments. We have been instrumental in the development of the MUSE experiment at PSI for which we built and commissioned the scintillation detectors. We have developed software to model experiments and detectors and to readout and calibrate detectors.

Looking to the future of precision QCD studies in the regimes where sea-quark and gluon dynamics is prominent, we have been steadily contributing to detector development for the future Electron Ion Collider in the U.S. and to the physics case for an energy upgrade of the electron accelerator at Jefferson Lab at the luminosity frontier.

In addition to advancing discoveries and understanding in nuclear physics, a major goal of this project is to promote teaching, training, and learning. The project created new experimental, theoretical, technical, and computational opportunities for the education of undergraduate and graduate scientific personnel. Our program gave junior personnel exposure to science at the local, national, and international levels and guided them to acquire the technical, communication, and scientific skills necessary to become successful members of the scientific community. In this project we have trained nine graduate and four undergraduate students. Within this project, four of our students graduated with a Ph.D. degree and one student obtained a Master's degree. The large majority of our trainees have pursued successful careers in nuclear science and the industry.

We have been active in professional service to the nuclear community and in promoting nuclear physics. Members of our group have organized several international workshops, dedicated hadronic-physics sessions at conferences, and have served on several International Advisory Committees. We have given lectures at international summer schools and have been active in promoting interest in science and technology among K-12 students. We acted as judges and mentors at regional science fairs and the annual UofSC Midway Physics Day. These efforts increase the community's awareness and enjoyment of science.
